translated_meaning: The land belongs to those who are buried in it
cultural_notes: Establishes ancestral right to land ownership.

proverb: Tsi ya bakulu ke vandaka na ndombe
translated_meaning: The land of the elders cannot be traded like charcoal
cultural_notes: Used against commodification of sacred land.

translated_meaning: The soil is not an orphan
cultural_notes: Implies every land has ancestral ties and witnesses.

translated_meaning: Truth and the land sit on the same stool
cultural_notes: Land issues must be judged truthfully and traditionally.

translated_meaning: He who plants without permission loses even his sweat
cultural_notes: Used to affirm rightful land claims through authority.

translated_meaning: The land has ears
cultural_notes: Spoken to warn against injustice on sacred land.

proverb: Zan ti si li mo kpalo
translated_meaning: The land curses the one who steals it
cultural_notes: Land theft is viewed as a spiritual violation.

translated_meaning: Judgment walks with the soil
cultural_notes: Truth tied to land decisions will surface eventually.

translated_meaning: The land cannot be cut into lies
cultural_notes: Used in land court to reject forged claims.

translated_meaning: The land remembers better than men
cultural_notes: Land is said to carry intergenerational memory.

translated_meaning: There is no homestead without a rightful heir
cultural_notes: Affirms ancestral lineage as basis for land inheritance.

translated_meaning: The land does not rot with the dead
cultural_notes: Used to express continuity of land across generations.

proverb: Nthĩ ni ya atumia na athambĩ
translated_meaning: The land belongs to women and the priests
cultural_notes: Sacred authority over land rests in spiritual and maternal lines.

translated_meaning: The land is the house of God
cultural_notes: Land desecration is both legal and spiritual violation.

proverb: Lafti abbaa hin qaban, abbaa irraa fudhatan
translated_meaning: The land has no master; it was taken from someone
cultural_notes: Reminds of the impermanence of land claims.

translated_meaning: The land cannot be deceived
cultural_notes: Truth is revealed through how land responds to injustice.

translated_meaning: Farming the land has roots
cultural_notes: True ownership is earned through consistent labor and presence.

translated_meaning: Ancestral land is not for division
cultural_notes: Used to protect clan land from fragmentation.

translated_meaning: A land dispute kills, but it also reveals truth
cultural_notes: Land cases are high-stakes but reveal true lineage.

proverb: Piny ma nyig me gi dong cen
translated_meaning: A land trampled unjustly will turn back
cultural_notes: Unjust land conquest invites reversal or curses.

translated_meaning: The land does not owe anyone
cultural_notes: Invoked during land inheritance disputes.

proverb: Ilẹ̀ kì í jẹ́ kí ẹni tí kò mọ̀ọ́ mọ ibi tí a ti ń ṣeré
translated_meaning: The land does not let the ignorant know where play ends and ritual begins
cultural_notes: Used to warn outsiders against interfering in sacred land matters.

translated_meaning: The land has eyes
cultural_notes: Spoken to warn against unjust land acquisition.

proverb: Asase yɛ duru sen ade a ɔde no bɛdi
translated_meaning: The land is heavier than anything you use to claim it
cultural_notes: Invoked during chieftaincy land disputes.

proverb: Ŋutifafa me le dzodzro me, eye xɔse mele asi ŋu
translated_meaning: Peace is in the judgment, and the land's anger lies in the hand
cultural_notes: Common during village reconciliation ceremonies.

translated_meaning: The owner of the field is known
cultural_notes: Used in land ownership mediation.

translated_meaning: A lie does not till the land
cultural_notes: Emphasizes the power of truth in land disputes.

proverb: Suñuy mbedd mi mooy sunu alal
translated_meaning: Our streets are our inheritance
cultural_notes: Used in defense of communal urban spaces.

proverb: Baal bi xam na ndox mi ci mbindeem
translated_meaning: The baobab knows the water in its roots
cultural_notes: Used during land debates involving lineage or water rights.

proverb: Ngohun lu nyandeh ndɔɔ be nyandeh
translated_meaning: Land can bless or bury
cultural_notes: Spoken in rituals or trials about sacred land.
